etymologies: late Middle English: from late Latin chymus, from Greek khūmos ‘juice’ (compare with chyle). The Greek words khūlos and khūmos are from the same root and more or less identical in sense

definitions: the pulpy acidic fluid which passes from the stomach to the small intestine, consisting of gastric juices and partly digested food.
shortDefinitions: pulpy acidic fluid which passes from stomach to small intestine, consisting of gastric juices and partly digested food
